section.title: The Coordinate Plane
section.p:
The Cartesian coordinate plane is formed by drawing perpendicular coordinate axes starting at a point called the origin. The location of a point \mathcal{P} in the plane is determined by an ordered pair of real numbers (x,y) called its coordinates. The first coordinate x of the pair determines the location of \mathcal{P} along the horizontal axis and the second coordinate y of the pair determines its location along the vertical axis.
The origin \mathcal{O} has coordinates (0,0). Points on the x-axis have coordinates \mathcal{Q}(x,0), with the second coordinate zero. Similarly, points on the y-axis have coordinates \mathcal{R}(0,y), with the first coordinate zero.

statement.p:
The coordinate axes divides the plane into four quadrants labeled by roman numerals counter-clockwise:
Quadrant I refers to points (x,y) with x \gt 0 and y \gt 0 .
Quadrant II refers to points (x,y) with x \lt 0 and y \gt 0 .
Quadrant III refers to points (x,y) with x \lt 0 and y \lt 0 .
Quadrant IV refers to points (x,y) with x \gt 0 and y \lt 0 .
Points on an axis are not in any of the four quadrants.
Plot the points P(-3,5), \mathcal{Q}(2,-4), \mathcal{R}(-1.5,-2.5), and \mathcal{S}(0,4) on the coordinate plane and determine the quadrant of each point, if applicable.

li.p: \mathcal{S} is on the y-axis so is not in any of the four quadrants.

statement.p:
Suppose \mathcal{P}(x_1,y_1) and \mathcal{Q}(x_2,y_2) are two points in the coordinate plane.
The distance between \mathcal{P} and \mathcal{Q} is found using the distance formula \left(\text{distance between $\mathcal{P}$ and $\mathcal{Q}$}\right) = \sqrt{(x_2-x_1)^2 + (y_2-y_1)^2}.

section.p: Equation is a Pythagorean expression: sum the squares of the differences of corresponding coordinates and then take the positive square root of this. Note that the order of subtraction is irrelevant due to the squaring: (a-b)^2 = (b-a)^2.

example.title: The Equation of a Circle
example.p:
Suppose \mathcal{C}(a,b) is a point in the plane and r\gt 0 is a positive real number. The circle centered at \mathcal{C} with radius r consists of all points \mathcal{P}(x,y) satisfying
\left(\text{distance between $\mathcal{P}$ and $\mathcal{Q}$}\right) = r
From the Distance Formula ,
\sqrt{(x-a)^2+(y-b)^2}= r. It is convenient to square both sides of this equation to remove the radical and obtain the following equation of a circle (x-a)^2+(y-b)^2=r^2. For example (x-2)^2 + (y+3)^2 = 16 is the equation of the circle with center \mathcal{C}(2,-3) and radius \sqrt{16}=4.

section.title: Graphing Equations
section.p:
Consider the equation
x^2+y^2 = 1 with two variables x and y. Solutions to the equation are points (x,y) that make the equation TRUE. (See .) The set of all points in the coordinate plane that satisfy the equation is called the graph of the equation. For instance, \mathcal{P}(1,0) satisfies 1^2 + 0^2 = 1 so that \mathcal{P}(1,0) is a point on the graph of the equation. Consider \mathcal{Q}\left(0,-1\right) 0^2 + \left(-1\right)^2 = 0+1 = 1, so that \mathcal{Q} is on the graph of the equation. Similarly, \left(-\frac{1}{2}\right)^2 + \left(-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)^2 = \frac{1}{4}+\frac{3}{4} = 1 so that \mathcal{R}\left(-\frac{1}{2},-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right) is also on the graph. If we plot these three solutions in the coordinate plane we obtain just a portion of the graph of x^2+y^2=1.
To better understand the graph of this equation, we can rewrite things as
x^2+y^2 \amp= 1 (x-0)^2+(y-0)^2 \amp= 1 \sqrt{(x-0)^2+(y-0)^2} \amp= 1The left side looks like the Distance Formula . This says that (x,y) is a solution precisely when the distance between (x,y) and the origin (0,0) is 1. The set of all points that are one unit from the origin forms a circle centered at the origin with radius 1 and it is this circle which is the graph of x^2+y^2 = 1. We call this the unit circle.
Graph of the unit circle x^2+y^2=1 .

statement.p: Describe the graph of the equations x=2 and y=0 in the coordinate plane.

solution.p: The graph of the equation x=2 consists of all points (x,y) with a first coordinate of 2. These are the points (2,y), where y is any real number. Plotting each of these points results in a vertical line.
The graph of the equation y=0 consists of all points (x,0), where x is any real number. Plotting each of these points results in the horizontal line formed by the x-axis.

paragraphs.title: Standard Form
paragraphs.p:
A linear equation is any equation equivalent to one of the form Ax+By = C, where A, B and C are real numbers, and not both of A and B are zero. We call standard form. For example, y = \frac{2}{3}x + 5 is a linear equation, but not in standard form. Rewriting,
y = \frac{2}{3}x + 5 3y = 2x + 15 3y-2x = 15
which is now in standard form.

The graph of a linear equation is a line in the coordinate plane.
Typically, but not always, this line will intersect the coordinate axes at an intercept. The x-intercept is at the point \mathcal{P}(x,0) on the line with y = 0. Similarly, y-interceptis at the point \mathcal{Q}(0,y) on the line with x = 0. To find these points, substitute zero for the appropriate variable and solve for the other. If a line has two intercepts, this is sufficient to draw the graph.

example.title: Graphing a Line in Standard Form

statement.p: Find the intercepts of 3y-2x = 15 and sketch its graph.

solution.p:
To find the x-intercept, set y=0 and solve.
3(0)-2x = 15 -2x = 15 x = -\frac{15}{2}So there is an x-intercept at \left(-\frac{15}{2},\, 0)\right) .

To find the y-intercept, set x=0 and solve.
3y-2(0) = 15 3y = 15 y = 5So there is a y-intercept at \left(0,5\right).
Plotting these two points and drawing the line, we obtain its graph.

section.title: Slope and Rates of Change
section.p: Linear equations can provide simple models of real-life scenarios. The essential feature of a linear model is a constant rate of change determined by the slope of the line.

example.title: Linear Model of Data
example.p:
Researchers collected data on the number of hours students studied for an important professional certification exam. They performed a common statistical technique called linear regression to establish a best-fit linear model of the data and found the linear relationship S = 4.5H + 40, where H is the number of hours studied and S is the predicted score on the exam.
For each hour of studying, the model predicts an increased score of 4.5 points. This rate of change of 4.5 points per hour is seen graphically in the steepness or slope of the graph of the line.

definition.title: Slope of a Line
definition.p:
The slope m of a line in the coordinate plane is the ratio of the change in y over the change in x between any two different points on the line.
Precisely, suppose \mathcal{P}(x_1,y_1) and \mathcal{Q}(x_2,y_2) are two points on a line with x_1 \neq x_2. Then m = \left(\text{slope}\right) = \frac{\text{change in $y$}}{\text{change in $x$}} = \frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1} = \frac{\Delta y}{\Delta x} = \frac{\text{rise}}{\text{run}}

section.p: The symbol m is commonly used for the slope of a line. The vertical change in y is often called the rise and is denoted \Delta y, where the Greek letter "delta" is used to indicate change (difference). Similarly, horizontal change in x is often called the run and is denoted \Delta x.

statement.p: Find the slope of the line between the two points (-2,8) and (10,4)

solution.p:
Compute rise over run from the given points, being sure to maintain the correct order when subtracting: m = \frac{\Delta y}{\Delta x} = \frac{4-8}{10-(-2)} = \frac{-4}{12} = -\frac{1}{3}. The slope is negative, indicating that an
increase of 3 unitsin the x-coordinate will result in a
decrease of 1 unitin the y-coordinate.

paragraphs.title: Horizontal and Vertical Lines
paragraphs.p: The graph of a linear equation of the form y=k is a horizontal line and its slope is zero. This is because a change in x results in no change in y. On the other hand, a linear equation of the form x=h is a vertical line and its slope is undefined. This is because the change in the x-coordinates between any two points on the line is zero and we must never divide by zero.

example.title: Horizontal and Vertical Lines
example.p: The line y=-1 is horizontal with slope m=0, while the line x=2 is vertical with undefined slope.

section.title: Point-Slope Form
section.p:
Suppose we want to find the equation of a line passing through a known point \mathcal{P}(x_0,y_0) with a known slope m. We need to determine an algebraic equation that we can use to determine if a different point \mathcal{Q}(x,y) is or is not on the line. If \mathcal{Q} is on the line, then we can calculate the (known) slope m from these two points using the slope formula
m = \frac{y-y_0}{x-x_0}. Rewriting, we obtain the important point-slope form of the line y-y_0 = m(x-x_0).

statement.p: Let's find an equation for the line passing through the points (7,2) and (-3,-9).

li.p:
First, we need to determine its slope:
m = \frac{2-(-9)}{-3-7} = \frac{11}{-10} = - \frac{11}{10}.

Next, we can use point-slope form
and either of the known points. Using (7,2), y - 2 = -\frac{11}{10}(x-7).

section.p:
It would not be unusual to rewrite the last equation by solving for y. In the case of the previous example, we would have
y - 2 \amp= -\frac{11}{10}(x-7) y \amp= -\frac{11}{10}(x-7) + 2 y \amp= -\frac{11}{10}x+\frac{77}{10} + 2 y \amp= -\frac{11}{10}x+\frac{77}{10} + \frac{20}{10} y \amp= -\frac{11}{10}x+\frac{97}{10} y \amp= -1.1 x+9.7In this final form we can easily see two things: the slope m = -1.1 and the location of the y-intercept, for when x=0, y = 9.7. A linear equation in the form
y = mx + b is said to be in slope-intercept form. The slope of the line is m and the y-intercept is (0,b).

example.title: Sketching a Line in Slope-Intercept Form

statement.p: Sketch a graph of the line with equation y = 3x + 1.

solution.p: The line has y-intercept at (0,1) and slope m=3. Starting at the intercept, an increase of x by one unit will result in an increase of y by three units.

introduction.p:
Linear equations are frequently used to construct simple models of the interaction between two quantities. We will illustrate this with a few examples below. Think about the appropriate choice of linear form in each example.
Standard Form: Ax+By = C
Point-Slope Form: y-y_0 = m(x-x_0)
Slope-Intercept Form: y = mx+b

statement.p: A rectangular fence is to be constructed from a fixed budget of 1000 dollars. Two parallel sides of the fence are constructed from a material costing 4 dollars per foot, while the remaining sides are constructed from a material costing 3 dollars per foot. Express these constraints as a linear equation.

solution.p: Let x denote the length of the sides costing 4 dollars per foot and let y denote the length of the sides costing 3 dollars per foot. Then the cost of the fence is 4x+4x+3y+3y = 8x + 6y. The fixed budget imposes the linear constraint 8x+6y = 1000.

statement.p: A gasoline-powered generator has a fuel tank capacity of 10 gallons and consumes fuel at a rate 1.5 gallons per hour. Find a linear model for the fuel consumption over time. How long can the generator run on a full tank?

solution.p: Let y be the amount of fuel in the tank after running for x hours. Then initially, y=10, when x=0, determining the y-intercept. The rate of decrease of fuel provides the slope -1.5. So, y = -1.5x + 10. The tank will be empty when 0 = -1.5x + 10 which we solve to find x=10/1.5 \approx 6.7 hours.

statement.p: A company earns a revenue of \$1000 from selling 25 units of their product. They earn \$1650 from selling 41 units. Find a linear relationship modeling the revenue in terms of number of units sold.

solution.p:
Let R denote the revenue and x denote the number of units sold.
The data provided allows us to find the rate at which revenue changes as we increase the number of units sold: \frac{\Delta R}{\Delta x} = \frac{1650-1000}{41-25} = \frac{650}{16} = 40.625 So the slope of our line is m = 40.625 dollars per unit. We can now use point-slope form along with either data point to find a linear equation
R - 1000 \amp= 40.625(x-25) R \amp= 40.625(x-25)+1000 R \amp= 40.625(x-25)+1000 R \amp= 40.625x-15.625

section.title: Parabolas
section.p: A parabola is a curve that is defined by a special geometric property. Every point on a parabola is the same distance from a special point called its focus and a special line called its directrix. In the figure below the focus is labeled F and the directrix is labeled l. The parabola is the U-shaped curve. Observe the equal distances to the focus and directrix at the two points illustrated on the curve. The point V at the base of U-shape is called the vertex of the parabola.

example.p: Let's find an equation for the parabola with focus at F(0,1) and directrix y = -1.

Suppose P(x,y) is a point on the parabola. Then the distance from P to F is given by the Distance Formula (). \overline{PF} = \sqrt{(x-0)^2+(y-1)^2} = \sqrt{x^2+(y-1)^2}. The distance from P to the line y = -1 is \overline{Pl} = y+1. These distances must be equal so that \sqrt{x^2+(y-1)^2} = y+1. Squaring both sides gives x^2+(y-1)^2 = (y+1)^2. Expanding the squared terms x^2+y^2-2y+1 = y^2+2y+1 Canceling common terms from both sides: x^2-2y = 2y And combining like terms: x^2 = 4y So that y = \frac{1}{4} x^2 is an equation for our parabola.

introduction.p: In fact, a curve whose equation is given by a quadratic polynomial of the form y = ax^2+bx+c, where a\neq 0 has the graph of a parabola. In the demonstration below, move the sliders to consider the effect of each coefficient.

Graph the parabola y = -2 x^2+5 x+3 by finding the intercepts of the graph.

solution.p:
To find where the graph intersects the x-axis, we need to set y=0 and solve for x. This can be done, in this case, via factoring:
-2 x^2+5 x+3 \amp= 0 -(2 x^2-5 x-3 \amp= 0 -(2x+1)(x-3) \amp= 0
So that 2x+1=0 OR x-3 = 0. This gives x-intercepts at (-1/2,0) and (3,0).
